metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: R Lists
Lists
A list in R can contain many different data types inside it. A list is a collection of data which is ordered and changeable.
content.html: A list in R can contain many different data types inside it. A list is a collection of data which is ordered and changeable.

content.text: To create a list, use the list() function:
content.html: To create a list, use the list() function:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# List of stringsthislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
  # Print the list
  thislist

content.code:
# List of stringsthislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
# Print the list
thislist

syntax_highlighting.text:
# List of stringsthislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
 # Print the list
  thislist

content.code_html:
# List of strings
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

# Print the list
 thislist

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# List of stringsthislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
  # Print the list
  thislist

content.text: Access Lists
You can access the list items by referring to its index number, inside brackets. The first item has index 1, the second item has index 2, and so on:
content.html: You can access the list items by referring to its index number, inside brackets. The first item has index 1, the second item has index 2, and so on:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

thislist[1]

content.text: Change Item Value
To change the value of a specific item, refer to the index number:
content.html: To change the value of a specific item, refer to the index number:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")thislist[1] <- "blackcurrant"
  # Print the updated listthislist

content.code:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")thislist[1] <- "blackcurrant"
# Print the updated listthislist

syntax_highlighting.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")thislist[1] <- "blackcurrant"
 # Print the updated listthislist

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")
thislist[1] <- "blackcurrant"

# Print the updated list
thislist

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")thislist[1] <- "blackcurrant"
  # Print the updated listthislist

content.text: List Length
To find out how many items a list has, use the length() function:
content.html: To find out how many items a list has, use the length() function:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

length(thislist)

content.text: Check if Item Exists
To find out if a specified item is present in a list, use the %in% operator:
content.html: To find out if a specified item is present in a list, use the %in% operator:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

"apple" %in% thislist

content.text: Add List Items
To add an item to the end of the list, use the append() function:
content.html: To add an item to the end of the list, use the append() function:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

append(thislist, "orange")

content.text: To add an item to the right of a specified index, add " after= index number " in the append() function:
content.html: To add an item to the right of a specified index, add "after=index number" in the append() function:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

append(thislist, "orange", after = 2)

content.text: Remove List Items
You can also remove list items. The following example creates a new, updated list without an "apple" item:
content.html: You can also remove list items. The following example creates a new, updated list without an "apple" item:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")newlist <- thislist[-1]
  # Print the new listnewlist

content.code:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")newlist <- thislist[-1]
# Print the new listnewlist

syntax_highlighting.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")newlist <- thislist[-1]
 # Print the new listnewlist

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

newlist <- thislist[-1]

# Print the new list
newlist

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")newlist <- thislist[-1]
  # Print the new listnewlist

content.text: Range of Indexes
You can specify a range of indexes by specifying where to start and where to end the range, by using the : operator:
content.html: You can specify a range of indexes by specifying where to start and where to end the range, by using the : operator:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "kiwi", "melon", "mango")

(thislist)[2:5]

content.text: Note: The search will start at index 2 (included) and end at index 5 (included).
content.html: Note: The search will start at index 2 (included) and end at index 5 (included).

content.text: Remember that the first item has index 1.
content.html: Remember that the first item has index 1.

content.text: Loop Through a List
You can loop through the list items by using a for loop:
content.html: You can loop through the list items by using a for loop:

content.code_html:
thislist <- list("apple", "banana", "cherry")

for (x in thislist) {
  print(x)
}

content.text: Join Two Lists
There are several ways to join, or concatenate, two or more lists in R.
content.html: There are several ways to join, or concatenate, two or more lists in R.

content.text: The most common way is to use the c() function, which combines two elements together:
content.html: The most common way is to use the c() function, which combines two elements together:

content.code_html:
list1 <- list("a", "b", "c")
list2 <- list(1,2,3)
list3 <- c(list1,list2)

list3
